channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Cause of Crises? For Rio Governor, Life Incriminates Art
item.description: As problems grow in Rio de Janeiro State seven months before it hosts the Olympics, its governor, Luiz Fernando de Souza, partly blames a painting that was in his office.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: Protest Over Higher Bus Fares Erupt in 3 Cities
item.description: Demonstrations in São Paulo, Rio de Janeiro and Belo Horizonte reflected resentment over efforts to cover budget shortfalls.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Mali: Swiss Woman Is Kidnapped for a Second Time
item.description: The woman, briefly abducted in 2012, was kidnapped again by suspected jihadists who scaled the walls of her home.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Sri Lanka: Leader Frees Man Jailed in Plot to Kill Him
item.description: President Maithripala Sirisena pardoned a former Tamil Tiger insurgent accused of conspiring to kill him 10 years ago.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Creating a Cuteness Empire in Japan, One Fuzzy Bear Suit at a Time
item.description: Whimsical mascots have become almost as closely associated with Japan as Mt. Fuji and sushi, and the most successful ones are recognized by millions.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Japanese people have this desire to take the sharp edges off things, to take hard things and make them soft.”

item.title: ‘Mein Kampf,’ Hitler’s Manifesto, Returns to German Shelves
item.description: Scholars and historians spent three years preparing a nearly 2,000-page edition with about 3,500 annotations in anticipation of the work entering the public domain.
item.category: Documentation Center for the History of National Socialism (Munich, Germany)
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: The first edition of “Mein Kampf” to be published in Germany since Hitler’s reign ended over 70 years ago.

item.title: El Chapo, Escaped Drug Lord, Has Been Recaptured, Mexican President Says
item.description: Joaquín Guzmán Loera, also known as El Chapo, was caught in the city of Los Mochis, a seaside area in his home state, Sinaloa.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Office of the Mexican Attorney General
item.media:description: The drug kingpin Joaquín Guzmán Loera, also known as El Chapo, in a photo released on Friday by the office of the Mexican Attorney General.

item.title: 18 Asylum Seekers Are Tied to Attacks on Women in Germany
item.description: The police chief in Cologne was forced out amid a growing uproar over an assault on women that unfolded on New Year’s Eve and have stoked fears of newcomers.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Clinton-Blair Chats Inspire Online Satire, and Confusion
item.description: Dead-on satires of phone conversations between former President Bill Clinton and Tony Blair, then the British prime minister, from early 1997 to late 2000, sowed confusion online.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: French Proposal to Strip Citizenship Over Terrorism Sets Off Alarms
item.description: Critics say that the change, which would apply to dual citizens and is backed by a Socialist government tiptoeing to the right, would be un-French.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Seeing Miró’s Majorca Studio, Just the Way He Kept It
item.description: A re-creation of Joan Miró’s Mediterranean workplace is on exhibition, 60 years after he began working there.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Ludovic Maisant/Hemis.fr, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Joan Miró’s Majorca studio is the subject of a gallery exhibition.

item.title: Hundreds of Syrians Are Turned Back at Beirut Airport
item.description: Four hundred Syrians who were trying to fly to Turkey were stopped at the Beirut airport on Friday and were being forced to return to Damascus instead.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Gunmen Fire on Hotel in Egypt, Wounding Foreign Tourists
item.description: Local news media reports said the attackers had approached the Red Sea resort by boat and described them as carrying an Islamic State flag.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Drug Kingpin ‘El Chapo’ Has Been Arrested, Mexican President Says
item.description: The drug kingpin Joaquín Guzmán Loera , also known as El Chapo, has been arrested by Mexican authorities, the country’s president announced on Twitter.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Mexican drug trafficker Joaquin Guzman Loera in February 2014, in Mexico City.

item.title: ‘Skin Whitener’ Ad Sparks Criticism in Thailand
item.description: A beauty company has apologized for an ad with a model in blackface.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS
item.media:description: An online advertisement by Thai cosmetics company Seoul Secret showing Thai actress Cris Horwang, right, is displayed on a computer screen in Bangkok, Thailand.

item.title: Muslim Brotherhood Supporters Clash With Security Forces Outside Cairo Hotel
item.description: The Egyptian government attributed the violence to political unrest and said that tourists had not been directly targeted.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: A woman cleaned smashed glass off a hotel's facade in Cairo on Thursday.

item.title: White House Officials Meet With Tech Leaders on Thwarting Terrorists
item.description: The officials met Friday with technology executives to try to persuade them to do more to stop terrorists from using their platforms to recruit followers.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS and CECILIA KANG
item.media:description: Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, last month in New York. Mr. Cook and other technology executives will meet with top Obama administration officials on Friday.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Cartoon: Chappatte on a Detonation in North Korea
item.description: Testing, testing.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: Suspect in Tel Aviv Rampage Is Killed in a Shootout With Police
item.description: The man suspected of killing three Israelis a week ago in a shooting rampage died on Friday in a shootout with the police in northern Israel, officials said.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: News Analysis: With Nuclear Test, North Korea’s Leader Asserts Role of Instigator
item.description: Kim Jong-un is often dismissed as erratic, but this week he increased tensions between the United States and China and put more pressure on South Korea.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, manages his cult of personality carefully.
